ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned more about historical analysis of indentitarian conceptualizations. I gained insight into how projecting modern conceptualizations of identity onto people in the past is anachronistic and ill-suited to gaining understanding of the past. I gained a lot of historical contextualization for gender and sexuality in Japan which I found deeply interesting.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think this course was excellent. I greatly enjoyed the material. I think that the instructor should either choose to teach only on edo period japan or make the course into a survey course which gives a broader perspective on how japanese conceptions of gender and sexuality have developed over time.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course. It was deeply engaging and valuable to learn about gender and sexuality in another country. It was also interesting to see how ideas are exchanged and how European and US imperialist interactions with Japan played a part in the rise of homophobia in Japan. This class taught me to seek historical contextualization when learning and discussing identities with which I am unfamiliar. Overall, the class was very informative and interesting.
